PARAGRAPH.STRING: is a dormant shield volcano, rising to 3,110 metres (10,203 ft) and dominating the northwest part of Siple Island, which is separated from the Bakutis Coast, Marie Byrd Land, by the Getz Ice Shelf.
last erupted sometime during the Holocene.
is capped by a 4 x 5 km (2.5 x 3 mi) summit caldera, and tuff cones lie on the lower flanks.
massive volume of 1,800 cubic kilometres (430 cu mi) is comparable to that of Mount Erebus.

is named after Paul Allen Siple (1908-68), American Antarctic explorer and geographer who took part in six Antarctic expeditions, including the two Byrd expeditions of 1928-30 and 1933-35 (Siple Coast, Siple Island). He was in command of the West Base of the US Antarctic Service (USAS), 1939-41, and was navigator on all major exploratory flights from the base, including the flight on which

was discovered. He served as U.S. Army Senior Representative on Operation Highjump, 1946-47; as Director of Scientific Projects in the planning stages for the US-IGY; and as the inaugural scientific leader at the U.S. Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station 1956-57.
has probably been climbed, but there is no known record of the achievement . If
is the most prominent unclimbed mountain in the world (see highest unclimbed mountain).
